title: Antiguraleus infandus
text:
Antiguraleus infandus is a species of <a href="sea%20snail">sea snail</a>, a marine <a href="gastropod">gastropod</a> <a href="mollusk">mollusk</a> in the <a href="family%20%28biology%29">family</a> <a href="Mangeliidae">Mangeliidae</a>.
Description.
The length of the shell attains 6 mm, its diameter 3 mm.
(Original description) The shell is white and chalky. It contains 5 rounded <a href="Whorl%20%28mollusc%29">whorl</a>s, including a smooth <a href="protoconch">protoconch</a> of about 1½ whorl. The shell is longitudinally vertically ribbed, the ribs strong right up to the
suture and persisting faintly down the base. The <a href="body%20whorl">body whorl</a> shows about nine ribs. Strong spirals cross the ribs, two on the second whorl, three above the <a href="Aperture%20%28mollusc%29">aperture</a>, a fourth and faint fifth on the body-whorl. The sutures of the early whorls are sharp. of those succeeding concavely rounded. The base is spirally striated. The type is worn—the protoconch damaged, and the outer <a href="Lip%20%28gastropod%29">lip</a> broken away for a quarter of a whorl. There are spiral striations between the main spirals, and these are strongest on the somewhat hollow infrasutural tabulation. There is no anal fasciole.
Distribution.
This marine species occurs off <a href="Great%20Barrier%20Island">Great Barrier Island</a>, New Zealand.
